page.title: 04Rocks for drystone walling.
page.content: miles of dry stone walls. The traditional method of building these walls dates back at least 4000 years.First a shallow trench is dug about 60cm.wide and only 12cm.deep because the top strata of understone is very near the surface.2 large stones are placed in the bottom then 3 smaller stones on top sloping out so that if water got in it would run out. The wall continues upward in courses of three with an occasional through- stone or"jumper"for strength to about 70cm.On top flat stones are laid up- right called"toppers"or"shuckers".It is not a quick process - a skilled waller could lay a yard in a day the walls following the lie of the land.He used a stone axe to trim the stone to shape and a boy helped to fill the gaps with chips.Our characteristic walls continue to build in this way.
